thread.title: Soggy conditions can’t slow Liberty football's aerial attack
thread.title_full: Soggy conditions can’t slow Liberty football's aerial attack

title: Soggy conditions can’t slow Liberty football's aerial attack
text:
Complete Box Score » 
The once-white towel was a nasty brown by the time the game was over, two holes through the middle as it hung off of Doug Erney ’s belt. 
The Liberty quarterback had put the ragged cloth to good use, drying his hands as much as he could before taking each snap on a wet Thursday night at East Penn School District Stadium. 
“As you can see, it got a little beat up,” Erney laughed, looking at the towel. 
In turn, it helped him beat up on the Emmaus defense with his receivers in a 34-31 win . 
The rain that fell early in the first half and the soggy field that was left behind the rest of the way hardly tamed the Hurricanes – perhaps their namesake helped with the one approaching – as Erney threw for 230 yards and four touchdowns. 
“I actually felt we did a nice job with the conditions,” coach John Truby said. “Doug has so many weapons to choose from and he’s just the leader of our team. He had a really good game.” 
Erney completed 14 of 27 passes on the night, including 12 of 19 in the first half for 213 yards. Darian Street (lehighvalleylive.com file photo) 
Junior wide receiver Darian Street was shut out in last week’s win over Whitehall but came through in a big way Thursday, catching five passes for 44 yards and two touchdowns. 
“Doug Erney had a hell of a game,” Truby said. “Darian Street had a hell of a game.” 
The duo first connected on a four-yard touchdown pass in the first quarter to give Liberty the 14-10 lead. Erney led Street into the corner of the end zone and Street made a highlight-reel reception to secure the ball and get a foot inbound for the touchdown. 
“That was definitely a great catch,” Erney said. “I threw it a little too far and I kind of got scared, but I knew he’s athletic enough to make a wonderful catch like that.” 
They hooked up for the Hurricanes’ next touchdown in the second quarter, when Erney threw into a crowd of Emmaus defenders but put the ball right on the money and Street hauled it in for the 14-yard score. 
“Great catch and great blocking by the linemen,” Erney said. “(Street) wasn’t in the mix the first four games, so I’m glad we got another asset to the wide receiver core.” 
Street had caught eight passes for 89 yards and a touchdown through the first four games but was a much bigger factor Thursday night. 
He wasn’t Erney’s only option, though, as the quarterback also found Victor Santiago and Elijah Williams on touchdown passes. 
Erney’s receivers helped him out on those scores, too. Santiago caught the ball 10 yards deep on a slant and took off, beating the rest of the defense with his speed for the 66-yard touchdown. 
Williams didn’t appear to be headed to the end zone on his before he cut his way through the Emmaus secondary on a series of jukes to get in for the 41-yard score. 
“I’m glad my receivers pulled through for me today even though it was raining and stuff,” Erney said. 
“We knew we were gonna have a hard time with some of their guys in space,” Green Hornets coach Randy Cuthbert said. “We’re not the fastest team and that’s gonna give us some challenges.” 
Erney also created a few plays with his feet, finishing with 11 carries for 52 yards. 
“Their quarterback is tough to defend,” Cuthbert said. “He’s really good. I think he’s a great player.” 
Liberty went with a heavy dosage of the ground game in the second half to help chew up the clock. Gunner Anglovich took 12 carries for 73 yards and a touchdown while Nasir Legree added 12 rushes for 79 yards. 
The win propelled the Hurricanes to a 4-1 mark, their best start through five games since the 2008 state championship team. 
“It definitely feels good,” Erney said. “First time going 4-1 in my career. I’m glad my guys have the same mindset as me that we want to win every game. Not looking ahead in the future, going week-by-week and that’s what we’ve been doing so far and it’s been working out.” 
They adjusted on the fly this week when they found out Wednesday they’d be playing a day early due to weather concerns, and now they’ll have an extra day to prepare for their toughest foe yet. 
“It feels great to be 4-1 in a very tough conference,” Truby said. “We have a heck of a challenge coming into our house next week with Parkland. We’re going to get ourselves ready, rest up and get after them next week.”
